questions.question_text: What is normally used for ATIS broadcasts?
options: Discrete VHF frequency and/or VOR
Commercial telephone lines
Satellite communication
HF radio
questions.correct_answer: Discrete VHF frequency and/or VOR

questions.question_text: What are the four forces acting on an airplane in flight?
options: Power, Friction, Gravity, and Lift
Thrust, Drag, Gravity, and Inertia
Lift, Weight, Thrust, and Drag
Lift, Weight, Power, and Drag
questions.correct_answer: Lift, Weight, Thrust, and Drag

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of calculating weight and balance?
options: To ensure the aircraft is aesthetically pleasing.
To determine the fuel efficiency of the aircraft.
To ensure the aircraft is operated within its weight and center of gravity limits.
To calculate the maximum speed of the aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: To ensure the aircraft is operated within its weight and center of gravity limits.

questions.question_text: The 'empty weight' of an aircraft generally includes the weight of the airframe, engines, and standard equipment. What else is typically included?
options: The pilot and passengers.
All usable fuel.
Unusable fuel and undrainable oil.
Baggage and cargo.
questions.correct_answer: Unusable fuel and undrainable oil.

questions.question_text: What effect does an increase in an aircraft's weight have on its takeoff performance?
options: It has no effect on takeoff performance.
It shortens the takeoff roll.
It increases the takeoff distance.
It decreases the takeoff speed required.
questions.correct_answer: It increases the takeoff distance.

questions.question_text: How does a higher-than-standard-day temperature affect aircraft performance?
options: It improves engine performance.
It increases air density and improves lift.
It has no effect on performance.
It decreases air density and reduces performance.
questions.correct_answer: It decreases air density and reduces performance.

questions.question_text: What is pressure altitude?
options: The altitude indicated on the altimeter.
The altitude corrected for non-standard temperature.
The altitude read on the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 in Hg.
The actual height above the ground.
questions.correct_answer: The altitude read on the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 in Hg.

questions.question_text: What is density altitude?
options: The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature.
The altitude shown on the altimeter.
The actual height of the aircraft above ground level.
The height of the aircraft above mean sea level.
questions.correct_answer: The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would lead to an increase in density altitude?
options: A decrease in ambient temperature.
An increase in barometric pressure.
An increase in humidity.
A decrease in altitude.
questions.correct_answer: An increase in humidity.

questions.question_text: In the context of weight and balance, what is the 'reference datum'?
options: The aircraft's center of gravity.
The point from which all moment arms are measured.
The maximum allowable weight of the aircraft.
The location of the main landing gear.
questions.correct_answer: The point from which all moment arms are measured.

questions.question_text: What is the 'arm' in a weight and balance calculation?
options: The weight of an object.
The horizontal distance from the reference datum to an object's center of gravity.
The total weight of the aircraft.
The turning force of an object.
questions.correct_answer: The horizontal distance from the reference datum to an object's center of gravity.

questions.question_text: How is 'moment' calculated in weight and balance?
options: Weight / Arm
Weight + Arm
Weight x Arm
Weight - Arm
questions.correct_answer: Weight x Arm

questions.question_text: What is the 'useful load' of an aircraft?
options: The weight of the aircraft including all fuel and oil.
The weight of the pilot, copilot, passengers, baggage, usable fuel and drainable oil.
The maximum takeoff weight minus the empty weight.
The weight of the aircraft without any occupants or baggage.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum takeoff weight minus the empty weight.

questions.question_text: What is the definition of a 'forward center of gravity' condition?
options: The CG is located behind the aft CG limit.
The CG is located forward of the forward CG limit.
The aircraft is loaded within its CG range.
The aircraft's tail is heavier than its nose.
questions.correct_answer: The CG is located forward of the forward CG limit.

questions.question_text: What is a potential consequence of an excessively aft center of gravity?
options: Improved longitudinal stability.
Difficulty in flaring for landing.
Reduced cruise speed.
Instability and difficulty in recovering from a stall.
questions.correct_answer: Instability and difficulty in recovering from a stall.

questions.question_text: What information is found in the 'Limitations' section of the Pilot's Operating Handbook (POH)?
options: Recommended flight procedures.
A list of all installed equipment.
Airspeeds, weight limits, and powerplant limitations.
Information on the aircraft's history.
questions.correct_answer: Airspeeds, weight limits, and powerplant limitations.

questions.question_text: What is Vso?
options: The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration.
The never-exceed speed.
The maximum structural cruising speed.
The stalling speed in a specified configuration.
questions.correct_answer: The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in the landing configuration.

questions.question_text: What is Vs1?
options: The stalling speed in the landing configuration.
The never-exceed speed.
The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in a specified (clean) configuration.
The maximum flaps extended speed.
questions.correct_answer: The stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed in a specified (clean) configuration.

questions.question_text: What does the white arc on an airspeed indicator represent?
options: The normal operating range.
The flap operating range.
The caution range.
The never-exceed speed.
questions.correct_answer: The flap operating range.

questions.question_text: What does the green arc on an airspeed indicator represent?
options: The flap operating range.
The normal operating range.
The caution range.
The never-exceed speed.
questions.correct_answer: The normal operating range.

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the yellow arc on an airspeed indicator?
options: The flap operating range.
The normal operating range.
The caution range; smooth air only.
The never-exceed speed.
questions.correct_answer: The caution range; smooth air only.

questions.question_text: What does the red radial line on an airspeed indicator signify?
options: The maximum structural cruising speed.
The never-exceed speed (Vne).
The best angle-of-climb speed.
The stalling speed.
questions.correct_answer: The never-exceed speed (Vne).

questions.question_text: What is Vy?
options: Best angle of climb speed.
Best rate of climb speed.
Maneuvering speed.
Never-exceed speed.
questions.correct_answer: Best rate of climb speed.

questions.question_text: What is Vx?
options: Best rate of climb speed.
Best angle of climb speed.
Maneuvering speed.
Flap extended speed.
questions.correct_answer: Best angle of climb speed.

questions.question_text: When is it most appropriate to use Vx?
options: During a normal takeoff.
When clearing an obstacle at the end of the runway.
To reach cruise altitude in the shortest time.
During a descent.
questions.correct_answer: When clearing an obstacle at the end of the runway.

questions.question_text: What is Va, or maneuvering speed?
options: The speed at which full, abrupt control movements can be made without overstressing the airframe.
The maximum speed at which flaps can be extended.
The never-exceed speed.
The best rate of climb speed.
questions.correct_answer: The speed at which full, abrupt control movements can be made without overstressing the airframe.

questions.question_text: How does an increase in weight affect maneuvering speed (Va)?
options: It has no effect on Va.
It decreases Va.
It increases Va.
It makes Va equal to Vne.
questions.correct_answer: It increases Va.

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of a flight plan?
options: To inform ATC of your intended route for search and rescue purposes.
To calculate fuel consumption.
To determine the aircraft's weight and balance.
To check the weather for the flight.
questions.correct_answer: To inform ATC of your intended route for search and rescue purposes.

questions.question_text: For a VFR flight, what is the minimum fuel reserve required by the FAA for a daytime flight?
options: Enough fuel to fly to the destination only.
Enough fuel to fly to the destination and then for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.
Enough fuel to fly to the destination and then for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
Enough fuel to fly to the destination, and then to an alternate airport.
questions.correct_answer: Enough fuel to fly to the destination and then for 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.

questions.question_text: What is a 'true course'?
options: The course of the aircraft over the ground.
The course measured on a sectional chart with reference to a meridian.
The course corrected for wind.
The course steered by the pilot.
questions.correct_answer: The course measured on a sectional chart with reference to a meridian.

questions.question_text: What is 'magnetic variation'?
options: The error in the magnetic compass.
The angle between true north and magnetic north.
The change in magnetic heading due to wind.
The dip of the magnetic compass.
questions.correct_answer: The angle between true north and magnetic north.

questions.question_text: How do you convert a true course to a magnetic course?
options: By adding or subtracting magnetic deviation.
By adding or subtracting magnetic variation.
By applying a wind correction angle.
By referencing the altimeter.
questions.correct_answer: By adding or subtracting magnetic variation.

questions.question_text: What is 'magnetic deviation'?
options: The angle between true north and magnetic north.
The error in the magnetic compass due to magnetic fields within the aircraft.
The effect of wind on the aircraft's course.
The difference between indicated airspeed and true airspeed.
questions.correct_answer: The error in the a magnetic compass due to magnetic fields within the aircraft.

questions.question_text: How do you find the magnetic deviation for a particular aircraft?
options: On a sectional chart.
In the Airport/Facility Directory.
On a compass correction card located in the cockpit.
By contacting Flight Service.
questions.correct_answer: On a compass correction card located in the cockpit.

questions.question_text: What is a 'wind correction angle'?
options: The angle between the aircraft's heading and the desired course.
The angle between true north and magnetic north.
The error in the magnetic compass.
The difference between true airspeed and groundspeed.
questions.correct_answer: The angle between the aircraft's heading and the desired course.

questions.question_text: If you are flying a true course of 180° with a 20-knot wind from 270°, will your groundspeed be higher or lower than your true airspeed?
options: Lower
Higher
The same
It is impossible to determine.
questions.correct_answer: Higher

questions.question_text: What is the primary source for preflight weather information?
options: The evening news.
A Flight Service Station (FSS).
Another pilot.
The airport manager.
questions.correct_answer: A Flight Service Station (FSS).

questions.question_text: What is a METAR?
options: A terminal area forecast.
An aviation routine weather report.
An in-flight weather advisory.
A report of pilot weather observations.
questions.correct_answer: An aviation routine weather report.

questions.question_text: What is a TAF?
options: An aviation routine weather report.
A forecast of weather conditions for a specific airport.
A graphical representation of weather.
A pilot report.
questions.correct_answer: A forecast of weather conditions for a specific airport.

questions.question_text: What is a PIREP?
options: A terminal area forecast.
A report of weather conditions observed by a pilot in flight.
A surface weather observation.
A weather chart.
questions.correct_answer: A report of weather conditions observed by a pilot in flight.

questions.question_text: What does a takeoff and landing distance chart help a pilot determine?
options: The amount of fuel required for a flight.
The runway length required for takeoff and landing under various conditions.
The aircraft's maximum speed.
The best altitude for cruising.
questions.correct_answer: The runway length required for takeoff and landing under various conditions.

questions.question_text: What effect does a headwind have on takeoff distance?
options: It increases the takeoff distance.
It decreases the takeoff distance.
It has no effect on takeoff distance.
It makes takeoff impossible.
questions.correct_answer: It decreases the takeoff distance.

questions.question_text: What effect does a tailwind have on landing distance?
options: It has no effect on landing distance.
It decreases the landing distance.
It increases the landing distance.
It makes landing easier.
questions.correct_answer: It increases the landing distance.

questions.question_text: What is the effect of an upslope runway on takeoff performance?
options: It increases the takeoff distance.
It decreases the takeoff distance.
It has no effect on takeoff distance.
It improves acceleration.
questions.correct_answer: It increases the takeoff distance.

questions.question_text: How does a soft or wet runway surface affect takeoff performance?
options: It has no effect.
It decreases the takeoff roll.
It increases the takeoff roll.
It improves tire traction.
questions.correct_answer: It increases the takeoff roll.

questions.question_text: What is the primary use of a cruise performance chart?
options: To determine the best takeoff speed.
To calculate the fuel consumption, endurance, and true airspeed at various power settings.
To find the landing distance.
To check the aircraft's weight and balance.
questions.correct_answer: To calculate the fuel consumption, endurance, and true airspeed at various power settings.

questions.question_text: What is 'endurance' in the context of aircraft performance?
options: The maximum distance an aircraft can fly.
The maximum time an aircraft can remain airborne.
The maximum speed of the aircraft.
The rate of fuel consumption.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum time an aircraft can remain airborne.

questions.question_text: What is 'range' in the context of aircraft performance?
options: The maximum time an aircraft can fly.
The maximum distance an aircraft can fly over the ground.
The maximum altitude an aircraft can reach.
The speed at which the aircraft burns the least fuel.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum distance an aircraft can fly over the ground.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a crosswind and headwind component chart?
options: To determine the total wind speed.
To find the headwind and crosswind components of the wind for a given runway.
To calculate the true airspeed.
To check for turbulence.
questions.correct_answer: To find the headwind and crosswind components of the wind for a given runway.

questions.question_text: What is the 'demonstrated crosswind component'?
options: The maximum crosswind in which a pilot is allowed to land.
The maximum crosswind that was demonstrated during aircraft certification.
The crosswind component that requires a specific pilot skill level.
The minimum crosswind for which a rudder is effective.
questions.correct_answer: The maximum crosswind that was demonstrated during aircraft certification.

questions.question_text: What is 'indicated airspeed' (IAS)?
options: The speed of the aircraft relative to the air.
The speed shown on the airspeed indicator.
The airspeed corrected for instrument error.
The airspeed corrected for temperature and pressure.
questions.correct_answer: The speed shown on the airspeed indicator.

questions.question_text: What is 'calibrated airspeed' (CAS)?
options: Indicated airspeed corrected for installation and instrument errors.
The speed of the aircraft relative to the ground.
The airspeed corrected for compressibility effects.
The speed shown on the airspeed indicator.
questions.correct_answer: Indicated airspeed corrected for installation and instrument errors.

questions.question_text: What is 'true airspeed' (TAS)?
options: The speed of the aircraft through the air.
The speed shown on the airspeed indicator.
The speed of the aircraft over the ground.
The airspeed corrected for wind.
questions.correct_answer: The speed of the aircraft through the air.

questions.question_text: What is 'groundspeed' (GS)?
options: The speed of the aircraft relative to the air.
The speed of the aircraft over the ground.
The speed shown on the airspeed indicator.
The true airspeed corrected for temperature.
questions.correct_answer: The speed of the aircraft over the ground.

questions.question_text: How is TAS affected by an increase in altitude, assuming a constant IAS?
options: TAS decreases.
TAS remains the same.
TAS increases.
TAS becomes equal to GS.
questions.correct_answer: TAS increases.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Normal Procedures' section of the POH?
options: To provide information on emergency situations.
To list the aircraft's limitations.
To describe the recommended procedures for normal operations.
To detail the aircraft's systems.
questions.correct_answer: To describe the recommended procedures for normal operations.

questions.question_text: What is a 'checklist' used for in aviation?
options: To help the pilot remember all necessary tasks for a particular phase of flight.
To calculate weight and balance.
To navigate.
To communicate with ATC.
questions.correct_answer: To help the pilot remember all necessary tasks for a particular phase of flight.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Emergency Procedures' section of the POH?
options: To describe normal flight operations.
To provide checklists and procedures for dealing with various emergencies.
To list the aircraft's performance data.
To detail the aircraft's weight and balance information.
questions.correct_answer: To provide checklists and procedures for dealing with various emergencies.

questions.question_text: If you experience an engine failure shortly after takeoff, what is generally the best course of action?
options: Immediately turn back to the runway.
Establish the best glide speed and select a suitable landing area ahead.
Attempt to restart the engine.
Increase the pitch to gain altitude.
questions.correct_answer: Establish the best glide speed and select a suitable landing area ahead.

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the best glide speed (Vg)?
options: It provides the greatest forward distance for a given loss of altitude.
It is the fastest speed the aircraft can fly.
It is the speed for maximum endurance.
It is the speed used for normal landings.
questions.correct_answer: It provides the greatest forward distance for a given loss of altitude.

questions.question_text: What is a 'sectional chart'?
options: A chart that shows the aircraft's internal components.
Aeronautical chart for VFR navigation.
A chart depicting weather patterns.
A chart used for IFR flights.
questions.correct_answer: Aeronautical chart for VFR navigation.

questions.question_text: What does a line of latitude measure?
options: Distance east or west of the Prime Meridian.
Distance north or south of the Equator.
Magnetic variation.
Altitude.
questions.correct_answer: Distance north or south of the Equator.

questions.question_text: What does a line of longitude measure?
options: Distance north or south of the Equator.
Distance east or west of the Prime Meridian.
Elevation.
Magnetic heading.
questions.correct_answer: Distance east or west of the Prime Meridian.

questions.question_text: What is a 'nautical mile'?
options: A unit of distance equal to one minute of latitude.
A unit of speed.
A unit of weight.
A unit of volume.
questions.correct_answer: A unit of distance equal to one minute of latitude.

questions.question_text: How do you identify an airport with a hard-surfaced runway on a sectional chart?
options: A circular symbol.
A tick mark next to the airport symbol.
The runway layout is depicted.
A star symbol.
questions.correct_answer: The runway layout is depicted.

questions.question_text: What does a star above an airport symbol on a sectional chart indicate?
options: The airport has a rotating beacon.
The airport is closed.
The airport has fuel available.
The airport is a military base.
questions.correct_answer: The airport has a rotating beacon.

questions.question_text: What does the color of an airport's rotating beacon indicate?
options: The runway length.
The type of airport (civilian, military, etc.).
The availability of fuel.
The time of day.
questions.correct_answer: The type of airport (civilian, military, etc.).

questions.question_text: What does a 'tick mark' next to an airport symbol on a sectional chart indicate?
options: The airport has services such as fuel.
The airport is a private airport.
The airport has a control tower.
The airport is restricted.
questions.correct_answer: The airport has services such as fuel.

questions.question_text: What is a 'visual checkpoint' on a sectional chart?
options: A point on the ground used for navigation by visual reference.
A point where a pilot must contact ATC.
An airport with a control tower.
A point where the magnetic variation changes.
questions.correct_answer: A point on the ground used for navigation by visual reference.

questions.question_text: What is 'pilotage'?
options: Navigating by reference to instruments.
Navigating by reference to visible landmarks on the ground.
Communicating with ATC.
Flying an aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: Navigating by reference to visible landmarks on the ground.

questions.question_text: What is 'dead reckoning'?
options: Navigating by calculating position based on a previously known position, course, speed, and time.
Navigating by visual reference to landmarks.
Using GPS for navigation.
Following a VOR radial.
questions.correct_answer: Navigating by calculating position based on a previously known position, course, speed, and time.

questions.question_text: What is a VOR?
options: A type of radar.
A ground-based radio navigation aid.
A satellite-based navigation system.
A visual signaling device.
questions.correct_answer: A ground-based radio navigation aid.

questions.question_text: What is a 'radial' from a VOR?
options: A magnetic course from the VOR station.
A true course from the VOR station.
A line of equal magnetic variation.
A communication frequency.
questions.correct_answer: A magnetic course from the VOR station.

questions.question_text: What information does a VOR provide to the pilot?
options: Distance to the station.
The aircraft's position relative to a selected radial.
The aircraft's altitude.
The wind direction.
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft's position relative to a selected radial.

questions.question_text: What is DME?
options: A system that provides distance information from a ground station.
A type of autopilot.
A weather radar system.
A communication radio.
questions.correct_answer: A system that provides distance information from a ground station.

questions.question_text: What is GPS?
options: A ground-based navigation system.
A satellite-based radio navigation system.
A system for communicating with ATC.
A weather forecasting tool.
questions.correct_answer: A satellite-based radio navigation system.

questions.question_text: What is the primary advantage of GPS for aviation navigation?
options: It is not affected by weather.
It provides highly accurate position information.
It is only available in the United States.
It does not require any equipment in the aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: It provides highly accurate position information.

questions.question_text: What is a 'waypoint' in GPS navigation?
options: A physical landmark on the ground.
A predetermined geographical position.
A VOR station.
An airport.
questions.correct_answer: A predetermined geographical position.

questions.question_text: What is the primary function of a flight computer (E6B)?
options: To navigate the aircraft automatically.
To perform calculations related to time, speed, distance, fuel, and wind.
To communicate with ATC.
To display weather information.
questions.correct_answer: To perform calculations related to time, speed, distance, fuel, and wind.

questions.question_text: What can you calculate using the wind side of an E6B?
options: Fuel consumption.
True airspeed.
Groundspeed and wind correction angle.
Density altitude.
questions.correct_answer: Groundspeed and wind correction angle.

questions.question_text: How do you calculate fuel required for a flight?
options: By guessing based on the length of the trip.
By dividing the distance by the aircraft's top speed.
By considering the fuel burn rate, time en route, and required reserves.
By filling the tanks completely for every flight.
questions.correct_answer: By considering the fuel burn rate, time en route, and required reserves.

questions.question_text: What is a 'navigation log'?
options: A record of all communications with ATC.
A detailed plan of a flight, including checkpoints, courses, distances, and estimated times.
A maintenance record for the aircraft.
A list of all airports in the country.
questions.correct_answer: A detailed plan of a flight, including checkpoints, courses, distances, and estimated times.

questions.question_text: What is 'lost procedures'?
options: A set of actions to take if you become disoriented and are not sure of your position.
The procedures for recovering a lost item in the cockpit.
The process of filing a lost flight plan.
A method for finding a lost airport.
questions.correct_answer: A set of actions to take if you become disoriented and are not sure of your position.

questions.question_text: If you are lost, what is a good first step to take?
options: Continue flying in the same direction.
Climb to a higher altitude to get a better view and improve radio reception.
Descend to a lower altitude.
Shut down the engine to conserve fuel.
questions.correct_answer: Climb to a higher altitude to get a better view and improve radio reception.

questions.question_text: What is the emergency transponder code for a lost aircraft?
options: There is no specific code for a lost aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: There is no specific code for a lost aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is a 'diversion' in aviation?
options: Flying a different route for fun.
A planned change in the flight path to an alternate airport.
Losing your way during a flight.
Flying in a holding pattern.
questions.correct_answer: A planned change in the flight path to an alternate airport.

questions.question_text: What is a key consideration when planning a diversion?
options: The availability of in-flight movies at the alternate airport.
The distance to the alternate, fuel required, and weather conditions at the alternate.
The color of the runway at the alternate.
The number of other aircraft in the area.
questions.correct_answer: The distance to the alternate, fuel required, and weather conditions at the alternate.

questions.question_text: What is 'special use airspace'?
options: Airspace that is always open to all aircraft.
Airspace where activities must be confined because of their nature.
Airspace that is only for military aircraft.
Airspace above 18,000 feet.
questions.correct_answer: Airspace where activities must be confined because of their nature.

questions.question_text: What is a 'prohibited area'?
options: Airspace where flight is prohibited.
Airspace where flight is restricted to certain times.
Airspace where VFR flight is not allowed.
Airspace that is for military use only.
questions.correct_answer: Airspace where flight is prohibited.

questions.question_text: What is a 'restricted area'?
options: Airspace where flight is always prohibited.
Airspace where flight is subject to restrictions.
Airspace that is only for commercial airliners.
Airspace that has no flight rules.
questions.correct_answer: Airspace where flight is subject to restrictions.

questions.question_text: What is a 'military operations area' (MOA)?
options: Airspace where military training activities are conducted.
Airspace that is closed to all civilian aircraft.
Airspace where VFR flight is prohibited.
Airspace that is controlled by the military.
questions.correct_answer: Airspace where military training activities are conducted.

questions.question_text: What should a pilot do when flying through an MOA?
options: Fly at a very low altitude.
Exercise extreme caution and contact the controlling agency for traffic advisories.
Avoid the area at all costs.
Turn off all radios.
questions.correct_answer: Exercise extreme caution and contact the controlling agency for traffic advisories.

questions.question_text: What is an 'alert area'?
options: An area with a high volume of pilot training or unusual aerial activity.
An area where flight is prohibited.
An area with hazardous weather.
An area that is always active.
questions.correct_answer: An area with a high volume of pilot training or unusual aerial activity.

questions.question_text: What is a 'controlled firing area'?
options: An area where firing activities are conducted in a controlled environment.
An area where flight is prohibited.
An area that is not shown on aeronautical charts.
An area where pilots must have special clearance to enter.
questions.correct_answer: An area where firing activities are conducted in a controlled environment.

questions.question_text: What are 'temporary flight restrictions' (TFRs)?
options: Restrictions on flight that are put in place for a specific event or incident.
Permanent restrictions on flight.
Restrictions that only apply to IFR flights.
Restrictions that are not published.
questions.correct_answer: Restrictions on flight that are put in place for a specific event or incident.

questions.question_text: Where can a pilot find information about active TFRs?
options: From a Flight Service Station (FSS) or the FAA's TFR website.
On a sectional chart.
In the POH.
By asking another pilot.
questions.correct_answer: From a Flight Service Station (FSS) or the FAA's TFR website.

questions.question_text: What is a 'Notice to Airmen' (NOTAM)?
options: A notice containing information concerning the establishment, condition, or change in any aeronautical facility, service, procedure, or hazard, the timely knowledge of which is essential to personnel concerned with flight operations.
A weather forecast.
A flight plan.
A maintenance record.
questions.correct_answer: A notice containing information concerning the establishment, condition, or change in any aeronautical facility, service, procedure, or hazard, the timely knowledge of which is essential to personnel concerned with flight operations.

questions.question_text: What are the different types of NOTAMs?
options: NOTAM(D), FDC NOTAMs, and Pointer NOTAMs.
Local, regional, and national NOTAMs.
Weather, airport, and airspace NOTAMs.
Urgent, routine, and informational NOTAMs.
questions.correct_answer: NOTAM(D), FDC NOTAMs, and Pointer NOTAMs.

questions.question_text: What is an FDC NOTAM?
options: A NOTAM that contains regulatory information such as changes to an instrument approach procedure or airway.
A NOTAM that is distributed locally.
A NOTAM that has to do with airport conditions.
A NOTAM that is only for military pilots.
questions.correct_answer: A NOTAM that contains regulatory information such as changes to an instrument approach procedure or airway.

questions.question_text: Where can a pilot obtain NOTAM information?
options: From a Flight Service Station (FSS), DUATS, or the FAA's website.
Only from the airport manager.
Only by listening to the ATIS.
Only from another pilot.
questions.correct_answer: From a Flight Service Station (FSS), DUATS, or the FAA's website.

questions.question_text: Using a POH performance chart, if the pressure altitude is 4,000 feet and the temperature is 21°C, what is the density altitude?
options: Approximately 5,000 feet
Approximately 6,000 feet
Approximately 4,000 feet
Approximately 3,000 feet
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 6,000 feet

questions.question_text: Given a takeoff weight of 2,300 lbs, a pressure altitude of 2,000 feet, and a temperature of 30°C, what is the expected takeoff distance to clear a 50-foot obstacle?
options: This requires a specific POH chart to answer.
1,500 feet
2,000 feet
1,000 feet
questions.correct_answer: This requires a specific POH chart to answer.

questions.question_text: If the total moment is 85,000 in-lbs and the total weight is 2,400 lbs, what is the center of gravity?
options: 35.4 inches aft of the datum
28.2 inches aft of the datum
32.0 inches aft of the datum
40.1 inches aft of the datum
questions.correct_answer: 35.4 inches aft of the datum

questions.question_text: An aircraft has an empty weight of 1,500 lbs at a CG of 35.0 inches. If a pilot weighing 180 lbs is seated at an arm of 37.0 inches, what is the new CG?
options: 35.2 inches
36.1 inches
34.8 inches
35.0 inches
questions.correct_answer: 35.2 inches

questions.question_text: You are planning a flight of 250 NM. Your aircraft cruises at 120 knots TAS and has a fuel burn of 8 gallons per hour. How much fuel will you need for the flight, not including reserves?
options: 16.7 gallons
20.8 gallons
15.0 gallons
25.0 gallons
questions.correct_answer: 16.7 gallons

questions.question_text: On a cross-country flight, you plan to fly a true course of 090°. The winds are from 030° at 20 knots. Your true airspeed is 110 knots. What is your approximate magnetic heading and groundspeed?
options: This requires an E6B or flight planning software to solve accurately.
MH 100°, GS 120 knots
MH 080°, GS 100 knots
MH 090°, GS 110 knots
questions.correct_answer: This requires an E6B or flight planning software to solve accurately.

questions.question_text: If you are flying at a pressure altitude of 8,000 feet with an OAT of -10°C, and your calibrated airspeed is 115 knots, what is your true airspeed?
options: Approximately 133 knots
Approximately 125 knots
Approximately 115 knots
Approximately 140 knots
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 133 knots

questions.question_text: You are on a flight and have covered 60 NM in 30 minutes. What is your groundspeed?
options: 120 knots
100 knots
90 knots
150 knots
questions.correct_answer: 120 knots

questions.question_text: Your destination is 180 NM away. Your groundspeed is 90 knots. How long will it take to reach your destination?
options: 2 hours
1.5 hours
2.5 hours
1 hour
questions.correct_answer: 2 hours

questions.question_text: The wind is reported as 270 at 15 knots. You are landing on Runway 24. What are the headwind and crosswind components?
options: Approximately 13 knots headwind and 7.5 knots crosswind.
Approximately 10 knots headwind and 10 knots crosswind.
15 knots headwind and 0 knots crosswind.
0 knots headwind and 15 knots crosswind.
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 13 knots headwind and 7.5 knots crosswind.

questions.question_text: If a runway is 5,000 feet long and has a 2% upslope, what is the effective runway length increase for takeoff?
options: Takeoff distance is increased, not the effective length.
The effective length is decreased.
The effective length is increased by 100 feet.
The effective length is increased by 10%.
questions.correct_answer: Takeoff distance is increased, not the effective length.

questions.question_text: How does an aft CG position affect an aircraft's stall speed?
options: It has no effect.
It increases the stall speed.
It decreases the stall speed.
It makes the aircraft impossible to stall.
questions.correct_answer: It decreases the stall speed.

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between load factor and stall speed?
options: Stall speed increases in proportion to the square root of the load factor.
Stall speed decreases with an increase in load factor.
There is no relationship.
Stall speed increases directly with the load factor.
questions.correct_answer: Stall speed increases in proportion to the square root of the load factor.

questions.question_text: In a 60-degree level bank turn, what is the load factor?
options: 1 G
1.5 Gs
2 Gs
3 Gs
questions.correct_answer: 2 Gs

questions.question_text: How does frost on the wings of an airplane affect takeoff performance?
options: It improves lift.
It disrupts the smooth flow of air over the wing, decreasing lift and increasing drag.
It has no significant effect.
It reduces the weight of the aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: It disrupts the smooth flow of air over the wing, decreasing lift and increasing drag.

questions.question_text: What is the primary reason for filing a VFR flight plan?
options: It is required for all flights.
To ensure search and rescue services are initiated if the flight is overdue.
To get a discount on fuel.
To inform the FAA of your flight for traffic separation.
questions.correct_answer: To ensure search and rescue services are initiated if the flight is overdue.

questions.question_text: When must you close a VFR flight plan?
options: Within 30 minutes of your estimated time of arrival.
Upon arrival at the destination airport.
It closes automatically.
Only if you land at an airport with a control tower.
questions.correct_answer: Upon arrival at the destination airport.

questions.question_text: What does the term 'abeam' mean in the context of navigation?
options: Directly in front of the aircraft.
Directly behind the aircraft.
At a 90-degree angle to the side of the aircraft.
At a 45-degree angle to the front of the aircraft.
questions.correct_answer: At a 90-degree angle to the side of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is a 'dogleg' in a flight plan?
options: A sharp turn in the flight path.
A direct route between two points.
A route that follows a road or river.
A type of navigational error.
questions.correct_answer: A sharp turn in the flight path.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of a 'fuel totalizer'?
options: To measure the amount of fuel in the tanks.
To calculate and display fuel flow, fuel remaining, and endurance.
To automatically switch fuel tanks.
To warn of a low fuel state.
questions.correct_answer: To calculate and display fuel flow, fuel remaining, and endurance.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'basic empty weight' and 'licensed empty weight'?
options: There is no difference.
Basic empty weight includes unusable fuel and undrainable oil, while licensed empty weight does not.
Licensed empty weight is a term no longer in use; basic empty weight is the current standard.
Basic empty weight includes the weight of the pilot.
questions.correct_answer: Licensed empty weight is a term no longer in use; basic empty weight is the current standard.

questions.question_text: If a flight is made with the CG at the aft limit, what flight characteristics can be expected?
options: Increased longitudinal stability and higher stall speed.
Decreased longitudinal stability and lower stall speed.
No change in flight characteristics.
Difficulty in raising the nose during takeoff.
questions.correct_answer: Decreased longitudinal stability and lower stall speed.

questions.question_text: What is the effect of high humidity on engine power?
options: It increases engine power.
It decreases engine power.
It has no effect on engine power.
It only affects turbocharged engines.
questions.correct_answer: It decreases engine power.

questions.question_text: What is the primary factor that determines the performance of an aircraft on any given day?
options: The pilot's skill.
The color of the aircraft.
Density altitude.
The time of day.
questions.correct_answer: Density altitude.

questions.question_text: You are flying a triangular course with legs of 50 NM each. Your TAS is 100 knots, and there is a 20-knot wind from the north. How will the wind affect your total time en route compared to a no-wind condition?
options: The total time will be less.
The total time will be the same.
The total time will be greater.
It is impossible to determine.
questions.correct_answer: The total time will be greater.

questions.question_text: What is a 'standard rate turn'?
options: A turn at a rate of 3 degrees per second.
A turn at a bank angle of 30 degrees.
A turn that takes 3 minutes to complete 360 degrees.
A turn at the aircraft's maximum bank angle.
questions.correct_answer: A turn at a rate of 3 degrees per second.

questions.question_text: How can a pilot estimate the angle of bank required for a standard rate turn?
options: Divide the TAS in knots by 10 and add 7.
It is always 15 degrees.
Multiply the TAS in knots by 0.15.
It is not possible to estimate.
questions.correct_answer: Divide the TAS in knots by 10 and add 7.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Weight and Balance' section of the POH?
options: To provide information on how to load the aircraft and ensure it is within limits.
To list the weight of all aircraft components.
To give examples of weight and balance problems.
To explain the theory of aerodynamics.
questions.correct_answer: To provide information on how to load the aircraft and ensure it is within limits.

questions.question_text: What are 'isogonic lines' on a sectional chart?
options: Lines connecting points of equal magnetic variation.
Lines connecting points of equal elevation.
Lines indicating airways.
Lines showing the boundaries of controlled airspace.
questions.correct_answer: Lines connecting points of equal magnetic variation.

questions.question_text: What is the 'agonic line'?
options: The line of zero magnetic variation.
The line of maximum magnetic variation.
The equator.
The Prime Meridian.
questions.correct_answer: The line of zero magnetic variation.

questions.question_text: If an airport is listed as 'PRIVATE' on a sectional chart, what does this mean?
options: It is closed to the public and requires permission to land.
It is a military airport.
It has no services available.
It is only for IFR flights.
questions.correct_answer: It is closed to the public and requires permission to land.

questions.question_text: What is a 'visual approach slope indicator' (VASI)?
options: A system of lights to provide visual descent guidance during an approach to a runway.
A radio navigation aid.
A type of runway marking.
An instrument in the cockpit.
questions.correct_answer: A system of lights to provide visual descent guidance during an approach to a runway.

questions.question_text: What does a 'red over white' VASI indication mean?
options: You are on the proper glide path.
You are too high.
You are too low.
The VASI is out of service.
questions.correct_answer: You are on the proper glide path.

questions.question_text: What is a 'precision approach path indicator' (PAPI)?
options: A system of lights similar to a VASI but with the lights in a single row.
A ground-based radar system.
A type of instrument approach.
A marking on the runway.
questions.correct_answer: A system of lights similar to a VASI but with the lights in a single row.

questions.question_text: When approaching to land at an airport in Class D airspace, when must you establish two-way radio communication with the control tower?
options: Before entering the Class D airspace.
After entering the Class D airspace.
When you are on final approach.
It is not required.
questions.correct_answer: Before entering the Class D airspace.

questions.question_text: What is a 'runway incursion'?
options: Any occurrence at an aerodrome involving the incorrect presence of an aircraft, vehicle, or person on the protected area of a surface designated for the landing and takeoff of aircraft.
A safe and normal operation.
When an aircraft lands on the wrong runway.
When an aircraft takes off without clearance.
questions.correct_answer: Any occurrence at an aerodrome involving the incorrect presence of an aircraft, vehicle, or person on the protected area of a surface designated for the landing and takeoff of aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is the best way to avoid a runway incursion?
options: By maintaining situational awareness, listening to ATC instructions, and understanding airport signage and markings.
By flying at a high speed on the ground.
By not talking to ATC.
By closing your eyes while taxiing.
questions.correct_answer: By maintaining situational awareness, listening to ATC instructions, and understanding airport signage and markings.

questions.question_text: What is 'wake turbulence'?
options: Turbulence generated by the wings of an aircraft.
Turbulence caused by weather.
Turbulence found in mountainous areas.
Turbulence at high altitudes.
questions.correct_answer: Turbulence generated by the wings of an aircraft.

questions.question_text: When is wake turbulence most severe?
options: Behind a heavy, slow, and clean aircraft.
Behind a light, fast aircraft with flaps down.
In strong winds.
At high altitudes.
questions.correct_answer: Behind a heavy, slow, and clean aircraft.

questions.question_text: How can a pilot avoid wake turbulence when landing behind a large aircraft?
options: Stay above the large aircraft's flight path and land beyond its touchdown point.
Fly below the large aircraft's flight path.
Land as close as possible behind the large aircraft.
Wake turbulence is not a concern during landing.
questions.correct_answer: Stay above the large aircraft's flight path and land beyond its touchdown point.

questions.question_text: What is a 'short field' takeoff technique?
options: A technique used to take off in the shortest possible distance.
A normal takeoff.
A takeoff with a long ground roll.
A takeoff with no flaps.
questions.correct_answer: A technique used to take off in the shortest possible distance.

questions.question_text: What is a 'soft field' takeoff technique?
options: A technique used to take off from a soft or rough surface, keeping the nosewheel off the ground as much as possible.
A takeoff on a paved runway.
A takeoff with a tailwind.
A takeoff at a high speed.
questions.correct_answer: A technique used to take off from a soft or rough surface, keeping the nosewheel off the ground as much as possible.

questions.question_text: What is a 'short field' landing technique?
options: A technique used to land and stop in the shortest possible distance.
A normal landing.
A landing with a long rollout.
A landing without using flaps.
questions.correct_answer: A technique used to land and stop in the shortest possible distance.

questions.question_text: What is a 'soft field' landing technique?
options: A technique used to land on a soft or rough surface, holding the nosewheel off as long as possible.
A landing on a paved runway.
A landing with a strong headwind.
A landing at a high speed.
questions.correct_answer: A technique used to land on a soft or rough surface, holding the nosewheel off as long as possible.

questions.question_text: What is a 'go-around'?
options: Aborting a landing approach.
A maneuver to circle the airport.
A normal landing.
A type of takeoff.
questions.correct_answer: Aborting a landing approach.

questions.question_text: When is a go-around appropriate?
options: Anytime the pilot feels the approach is not safe or stable.
Only when instructed by ATC.
Never.
Only in an emergency.
questions.correct_answer: Anytime the pilot feels the approach is not safe or stable.

questions.question_text: What is the primary cause of an inadvertent spin?
options: A stalled aircraft with yaw.
Flying too fast.
A steep bank.
Engine failure.
questions.correct_answer: A stalled aircraft with yaw.

questions.question_text: What is the standard spin recovery procedure (PARE)?
options: Power to idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite the spin, Elevator forward.
Power full, Ailerons into the spin, Rudder with the spin, Elevator back.
Power to idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder with the spin, Elevator forward.
Power full, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite the spin, Elevator back.
questions.correct_answer: Power to idle, Ailerons neutral, Rudder opposite the spin, Elevator forward.

questions.question_text: What is 'hypoxia'?
options: A state of oxygen deficiency in the body.
A feeling of euphoria.
Disorientation.
Carbon monoxide poisoning.
questions.correct_answer: A state of oxygen deficiency in the body.

questions.question_text: At what altitude is supplemental oxygen recommended for pilots during the day?
options: Above 12,500 feet MSL for more than 30 minutes, and at all times above 14,000 feet MSL.
Above 5,000 feet MSL.
Only when feeling symptoms of hypoxia.
It is never required for VFR flights.
questions.correct_answer: Above 12,500 feet MSL for more than 30 minutes, and at all times above 14,000 feet MSL.

questions.question_text: What is 'carbon monoxide' poisoning and how can it be detected?
options: A colorless, odorless gas that can leak into the cabin; it can be detected with a CO detector.
A type of food poisoning.
A result of hyperventilation.
A side effect of high altitude flight.
questions.correct_answer: A colorless, odorless gas that can leak into the cabin; it can be detected with a CO detector.

questions.question_text: What is 'spatial disorientation'?
options: A state of confusion where a pilot cannot determine the aircraft's attitude, altitude, or airspeed in relation to the Earth.
Getting lost.
Forgetting the flight plan.
A medical condition.
questions.correct_answer: A state of confusion where a pilot cannot determine the aircraft's attitude, altitude, or airspeed in relation to the Earth.

questions.question_text: How can a pilot overcome spatial disorientation?
options: By trusting the flight instruments.
By looking outside.
By closing their eyes.
By shaking their head.
questions.correct_answer: By trusting the flight instruments.

questions.question_text: What are the 'five hazardous attitudes' in aviation?
options: Anti-authority, Impulsivity, Invulnerability, Macho, and Resignation.
Happy, Sad, Angry, Scared, and Confused.
Careful, Cautious, Prudent, Thoughtful, and Deliberate.
Fast, Slow, High, Low, and Turning.
questions.correct_answer: Anti-authority, Impulsivity, Invulnerability, Macho, and Resignation.

questions.question_text: What is 'aeronautical decision making' (ADM)?
options: A systematic approach to the mental process used by pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.
A type of autopilot.
A navigation technique.
A communication procedure.
questions.correct_answer: A systematic approach to the mental process used by pilots to consistently determine the best course of action in response to a given set of circumstances.

questions.question_text: What is the 'DECIDE' model of ADM?
options: Detect, Estimate, Choose, Identify, Do, and Evaluate.
Decide, Estimate, Comply, Inform, Decide, and Execute.
Determine, Evaluate, Choose, Implement, Decide, and Examine.
Detect, Examine, Comply, Inform, Do, and Evaluate.
questions.correct_answer: Detect, Estimate, Choose, Identify, Do, and Evaluate.

questions.question_text: What is 'risk management' in aviation?
options: The process of identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks.
Avoiding all risks.
Flying only in perfect weather.
A type of insurance.
questions.correct_answer: The process of identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks.

questions.question_text: What is the 'PAVE' checklist used for in risk management?
options: Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, and External pressures.
Position, Altitude, Velocity, and Engine.
Plan, Airport, VFR, and Emergency.
Proceed, Assess, Verify, and Execute.
questions.correct_answer: Pilot, Aircraft, enVironment, and External pressures.

questions.question_text: What is 'situational awareness'?
options: The accurate perception of the factors and conditions that affect the aircraft and the pilot.
Knowing the location of the nearest airport.
Being aware of the time.
Understanding how to use the GPS.
questions.correct_answer: The accurate perception of the factors and conditions that affect the aircraft and the pilot.

questions.question_text: How can a pilot maintain situational awareness?
options: By actively monitoring the environment, communicating effectively, and managing workload.
By focusing on only one task at a time.
By flying at a low altitude.
By not using a checklist.
questions.correct_answer: By actively monitoring the environment, communicating effectively, and managing workload.

questions.question_text: If a pilot changes their mailing address, how long do they have to notify the FAA?
options: 30 days
60 days
90 days
1 year
questions.correct_answer: 30 days

questions.question_text: To act as pilot in command of an aircraft carrying passengers, a pilot must have made within the preceding 90 days:
options: Three takeoffs and three landings in an aircraft of the same category, class, and type.
One solo flight.
A flight review.
An instrument proficiency check.
questions.correct_answer: Three takeoffs and three landings in an aircraft of the same category, class, and type.

questions.question_text: What is a 'flight review'?
options: A review of a pilot's skills and knowledge, required every 24 calendar months.
A preflight inspection.
A debriefing after a flight.
A type of flight plan.
questions.correct_answer: A review of a pilot's skills and knowledge, required every 24 calendar months.

questions.question_text: What are the requirements for a private pilot certificate?
options: At least 17 years of age, be able to read, speak, and understand English, hold at least a third-class medical certificate, and meet the aeronautical experience requirements.
At least 16 years of age and a high school diploma.
A college degree in aviation.
At least 18 years of age and a commercial pilot certificate.
questions.correct_answer: At least 17 years of age, be able to read, speak, and understand English, hold at least a third-class medical certificate, and meet the aeronautical experience requirements.

questions.question_text: What privileges and limitations apply to a private pilot?
options: A private pilot may not act as pilot in command of an aircraft that is carrying passengers or property for compensation or hire.
A private pilot can fly any aircraft.
A private pilot is not required to have a medical certificate.
A private pilot can only fly during the day.
questions.correct_answer: A private pilot may not act as pilot in command of an aircraft that is carrying passengers or property for compensation or hire.

questions.question_text: What is the 'sterile cockpit rule'?
options: A rule that prohibits non-essential conversations and activities during critical phases of flight (taxi, takeoff, landing, and below 10,000 feet).
A rule that requires the cockpit to be cleaned before every flight.
A rule about not talking to passengers.
A rule that only applies to airline pilots.
questions.correct_answer: A rule that prohibits non-essential conversations and activities during critical phases of flight (taxi, takeoff, landing, and below 10,000 feet).

questions.question_text: What is the difference between a 'category', 'class', and 'type' of aircraft?
options: Category refers to a broad classification (e.g., airplane, rotorcraft), class refers to a classification within a category (e.g., single-engine land, multi-engine sea), and type refers to a specific make and model.
They all mean the same thing.
Category refers to the size of the aircraft, class to its speed, and type to its manufacturer.
Category is for military aircraft, class for civilian, and type for experimental.
questions.correct_answer: Category refers to a broad classification (e.g., airplane, rotorcraft), class refers to a classification within a category (e.g., single-engine land, multi-engine sea), and type refers to a specific make and model.

questions.question_text: What is the 'fuselage' of an aircraft?
options: The main body of the aircraft.
The wings.
The tail.
The landing gear.
questions.correct_answer: The main body of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is the 'empennage'?
options: The tail assembly of an aircraft.
The engine.
The cockpit.
The propellers.
questions.correct_answer: The tail assembly of an aircraft.

questions.question_text: What are 'ailerons' used for?
options: To control the roll of the aircraft.
To control the pitch.
To control the yaw.
To slow the aircraft down.
questions.correct_answer: To control the roll of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is the 'elevator' used for?
options: To control the pitch of the aircraft.
To control the roll.
To control the yaw.
To increase lift.
questions.correct_answer: To control the pitch of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What is the 'rudder' used for?
options: To control the yaw of the aircraft.
To control the pitch.
To control the roll.
To steer on the ground.
questions.correct_answer: To control the yaw of the aircraft.

questions.question_text: What are 'flaps' used for?
options: To increase lift and drag, allowing for a steeper approach and a slower landing speed.
To increase the speed of the aircraft.
To steer the aircraft.
To improve fuel efficiency.
questions.correct_answer: To increase lift and drag, allowing for a steeper approach and a slower landing speed.

questions.question_text: What is 'trim' used for?
options: To relieve control pressures, making the aircraft easier to fly.
To make the aircraft go faster.
To steer the aircraft on the ground.
To communicate with ATC.
questions.correct_answer: To relieve control pressures, making the aircraft easier to fly.

questions.question_text: What is a 'pitot tube'?
options: A device that measures ram air pressure to determine airspeed.
A communication antenna.
A fuel vent.
A part of the landing gear.
questions.correct_answer: A device that measures ram air pressure to determine airspeed.

questions.question_text: What is a 'static port'?
options: A device that measures static air pressure, used by the altimeter, vertical speed indicator, and airspeed indicator.
An opening for cabin ventilation.
A drain for water.
A connection for ground power.
questions.correct_answer: A device that measures static air pressure, used by the altimeter, vertical speed indicator, and airspeed indicator.

questions.question_text: What happens if the pitot tube becomes blocked?
options: The airspeed indicator will become unreliable.
The altimeter will not work.
The engine will fail.
The radios will not transmit.
questions.correct_answer: The airspeed indicator will become unreliable.

questions.question_text: What happens if the static port becomes blocked?
options: The altimeter will freeze at the altitude where the blockage occurred, and the VSI will read zero.
The airspeed indicator will read zero.
The engine will lose power.
The flaps will not extend.
questions.correct_answer: The altimeter will freeze at the altitude where the blockage occurred, and the VSI will read zero.

questions.question_text: What is an 'alternate static source' and when would you use it?
options: A secondary source of static pressure for the flight instruments, used if the primary static port becomes blocked.
A backup radio.
A handheld GPS.
An emergency power supply.
questions.correct_answer: A secondary source of static pressure for the flight instruments, used if the primary static port becomes blocked.

questions.question_text: What is a 'magnetic compass' and what are its errors?
options: A self-contained direction-finding instrument; its errors include variation, deviation, magnetic dip, and acceleration/deceleration errors.
A GPS.
An instrument that shows the aircraft's attitude.
A communication device.
questions.correct_answer: A self-contained direction-finding instrument; its errors include variation, deviation, magnetic dip, and acceleration/deceleration errors.

questions.question_text: What is 'magnetic dip'?
options: The tendency of the compass to point down towards the magnetic pole.
The difference between true north and magnetic north.
An error caused by the aircraft's magnetic fields.
An error that occurs during turns.
questions.correct_answer: The tendency of the compass to point down towards the magnetic pole.

questions.question_text: When turning from a northerly heading, the magnetic compass will:
options: Lag behind the turn.
Lead the turn.
Be accurate.
Point to the south.
questions.correct_answer: Lag behind the turn.

questions.question_text: When turning from a southerly heading, the magnetic compass will:
options: Lead the turn.
Lag behind the turn.
Be accurate.
Point to the north.
questions.correct_answer: Lead the turn.

questions.question_text: When accelerating on an easterly or westerly heading, the magnetic compass will:
options: Indicate a turn to the north.
Indicate a turn to the south.
Be accurate.
Stop working.
questions.correct_answer: Indicate a turn to the north.

questions.question_text: What is a 'heading indicator' or 'directional gyro'?
options: A gyroscopic instrument that provides a stable heading reference and is not subject to the errors of a magnetic compass.
A magnetic compass.
A GPS.
A VOR indicator.
questions.correct_answer: A gyroscopic instrument that provides a stable heading reference and is not subject to the errors of a magnetic compass.

questions.question_text: Why must the heading indicator be periodically realigned with the magnetic compass?
options: Due to precession, a characteristic of all gyroscopes.
Because of magnetic variation.
Because of magnetic deviation.
It does not need to be realigned.
questions.correct_answer: Due to precession, a characteristic of all gyroscopes.

questions.question_text: What is an 'attitude indicator' or 'artificial horizon'?
options: A gyroscopic instrument that provides a visual indication of the aircraft's pitch and bank attitude.
An altimeter.
A vertical speed indicator.
A compass.
questions.correct_answer: A gyroscopic instrument that provides a visual indication of the aircraft's pitch and bank attitude.

questions.question_text: What is a 'turn coordinator'?
options: A gyroscopic instrument that shows the rate of turn and the rate of roll, and includes an inclinometer to indicate the quality of the turn.
A heading indicator.
An attitude indicator.
A magnetic compass.
questions.correct_answer: A gyroscopic instrument that shows the rate of turn and the rate of roll, and includes an inclinometer to indicate the quality of the turn.

questions.question_text: What does the 'inclinometer' or 'ball' in the turn coordinator indicate?
options: Whether the aircraft is in a coordinated turn (yawing correctly).
The angle of bank.
The rate of turn.
The pitch attitude.
questions.correct_answer: Whether the aircraft is in a coordinated turn (yawing correctly).

questions.question_text: If the ball in the turn coordinator is to the inside of the turn, the aircraft is in a:
options: Slip
Skid
Coordinated turn
Spin
questions.correct_answer: Slip

questions.question_text: What is a 'slip' in a turn?
options: A condition where the aircraft is yawing to the outside of the turn.
A condition where the aircraft is not turning enough for the angle of bank.
A coordinated turn.
A type of stall.
questions.correct_answer: A condition where the aircraft is not turning enough for the angle of bank.

questions.question_text: If the ball in the turn coordinator is to the outside of the turn, the aircraft is in a:
options: Skid
Slip
Coordinated turn
Dive
questions.correct_answer: Skid

questions.question_text: What is a 'skid' in a turn?
options: A condition where the aircraft is yawing to the inside of the turn.
A condition where the aircraft is turning too much for the angle of bank.
A coordinated turn.
A maneuver to lose altitude quickly.
questions.correct_answer: A condition where the aircraft is turning too much for the angle of bank.

questions.question_text: What is 'adverse yaw'?
options: The tendency of an aircraft to yaw in the opposite direction of the roll.
A desirable flight characteristic.
A type of turbulence.
An error in the magnetic compass.
questions.correct_answer: The tendency of an aircraft to yaw in the opposite direction of the roll.

questions.question_text: How is adverse yaw counteracted?
options: By using the rudder in the direction of the turn.
By using the ailerons.
By increasing power.
It cannot be counteracted.
questions.correct_answer: By using the rudder in the direction of the turn.

questions.question_text: What is 'p-factor'?
options: A tendency for an aircraft to yaw to the left at high power settings and high angles of attack.
A type of propeller.
A measure of engine performance.
A force that acts perpendicular to the direction of flight.
questions.correct_answer: A tendency for an aircraft to yaw to the left at high power settings and high angles of attack.

questions.question_text: What are the four left-turning tendencies of a single-engine propeller aircraft?
options: P-factor, spiraling slipstream, torque, and gyroscopic precession.
Lift, weight, thrust, and drag.
Ailerons, elevator, rudder, and flaps.
Adverse yaw, slips, skids, and spins.
questions.correct_answer: P-factor, spiraling slipstream, torque, and gyroscopic precession.

questions.question_text: What is 'spiraling slipstream'?
options: The slipstream from the propeller rotating around the fuselage and striking the left side of the vertical stabilizer.
A type of weather phenomenon.
A maneuver.
A component of the engine.
questions.correct_answer: The slipstream from the propeller rotating around the fuselage and striking the left side of the vertical stabilizer.

questions.question_text: What is 'torque' as a left-turning tendency?
options: The tendency of the aircraft to roll to the left in reaction to the right-turning propeller.
A measure of engine power.
A force that opposes thrust.
A type of structural stress.
questions.correct_answer: The tendency of the aircraft to roll to the left in reaction to the right-turning propeller.

questions.question_text: What is 'gyroscopic precession' as a left-turning tendency in a tailwheel aircraft?
options: When the tail is raised during takeoff, a force is applied to the top of the propeller, and the resultant force is felt 90 degrees ahead in the direction of rotation, causing a yaw to the left.
An error in the heading indicator.
A force that affects the ailerons.
A phenomenon that only occurs in helicopters.
questions.correct_answer: When the tail is raised during takeoff, a force is applied to the top of the propeller, and the resultant force is felt 90 degrees ahead in the direction of rotation, causing a yaw to the left.
